docs.text: The DNAnexus extension package is a plugin provided by Seqera Labs that enables the deployment of Nextflow pipelines on the DNAnexus cloud platform. Note The plugin requires a license key to be used. If you are interested, please contact us for an evaluation license at sales@seqera.io . A pre-built version of this application is available in DNAnexus platform at this link https://platform.dnanexus.com/app/nextflow-dx. Warning The plugin is still in beta version and some Nextflow functionalities are limited. See below for the known problems and limitations. Requirements # DNAnexus command line tools aka dx-toolkit. See here for details. Nextflow runtime version 21.04.0 or later. Valid license for DNAnexus extension package for Nextflow. Make tool (only for the project bundling). Known problems and limitations # Nextflow resume functionality is still not working properly. When the pipeline execution terminates abruptly the Nextflow log file is not uploaded the target project storage. Some Biocontainers may not work properly.
docs.title: Introduction

docs.text: DNAnexus command line tools aka dx-toolkit. See here for details. Nextflow runtime version 21.04.0 or later. Valid license for DNAnexus extension package for Nextflow. Make tool (only for the project bundling).
docs.title: Requirements

docs.text: Nextflow resume functionality is still not working properly. When the pipeline execution terminates abruptly the Nextflow log file is not uploaded the target project storage. Some Biocontainers may not work properly.
docs.title: Known problems and limitations

docs.text: 1.0.0-beta.2 # As of version 1.0.0-beta.2 directives cpus , memory , disk and accelerator are supported. When specified Nextflow look up for a machine type able to satisfy the requested resources. The machineType directive has in any case precedence, when specified any cpus , memory , disk and accelerator is ignored.
docs.title: Changelog

docs.text: As of version 1.0.0-beta.2 directives cpus , memory , disk and accelerator are supported. When specified Nextflow look up for a machine type able to satisfy the requested resources. The machineType directive has in any case precedence, when specified any cpus , memory , disk and accelerator is ignored.
docs.title: 1.0.0-beta.2

docs.text: In order to deploy the execution of a Nextflow pipeline in DNAnexus you will need to create a DNAnexus applet bundling the Nextflow runtime along the DNAnexus extension plugin and, optionally, the pipeline scripts. In alternative to bundling the pipeline in the DNAnexus applet, it can be pulled from a Git repository as is usually done by Nextflow. The Makefile included in this repository automates the creation of the DNAnexus applet for Nextflow using the following steps: Login in your DNAnexus workspace # 1 dx login Clone this repository in your computer using the following command # 1 2 git clone https://github.com/seqeralabs/xpack-dnanexus cd xpack-dnanexus Create the DNAnexus bundle including the Nextflow runtime # 1 make dx-pack The above command creates the bundle skeleton in the directory build/nextflow-app . Modify the app metadata # DNAnexus app requires a file named dxapp.json to configure the application deployment and parameters. A predefined app metadata file with the settings required for the Nextflow execution is available in this repository at the path app/dxapp.json . Modify it according your requirements. See the DNAnexus documentation for further details. Build the DNAnexus applet # 1 make dx-build The above command build the DNAnexus applet for Nextflow with the name nextflow-app ready to be executed.
docs.title: Create a custom pipeline bundle
Clone this repository in your computer using the following command

docs.text: 1 make dx-pack The above command creates the bundle skeleton in the directory build/nextflow-app .
docs.title: Create the DNAnexus bundle including the Nextflow runtime

docs.text: DNAnexus app requires a file named dxapp.json to configure the application deployment and parameters. A predefined app metadata file with the settings required for the Nextflow execution is available in this repository at the path app/dxapp.json . Modify it according your requirements. See the DNAnexus documentation for further details.
docs.title: Modify the app metadata

docs.text: 1 make dx-build The above command build the DNAnexus applet for Nextflow with the name nextflow-app ready to be executed.
docs.title: Build the DNAnexus applet

docs.text: The Nextflow app is available in the DNAnexus Tools library. To get started with: Sign-in the DNAnexus platform Navigate to the Nextflow app available at this link . Click on Install buttom to make it available in your workspace Note The use of this app requires an activation licenses provided by Seqera Labs. If you don't have it already please contact us at sales@seqera.io for obtaining an evaluation license free of charge.
docs.title: Getting started

docs.text: You can find below some examples to deploy the execution of Nextflow with the applet built from the app bundling guide. Declare the following environment variable with your XPACK-DNANEXUS license. 1 export NXF_XPACK_LICENSE=<YOUR LICENSE CONTENT> Launching classic NF Hello world app # 1 2 3 dx run nextflow-app \ --watch \ --input-json "$(envsubst < examples/hello.json)" The above snippet runs the Nextflow hello pipeline. The Nextflow log file will be uploaded in your DNAnexus project root. You can access with the following command: 1 dx cat nextflow.log Launching simple RNAseq pipeline using container execution # 1 2 3 dx run nextflow-app \ --watch \ --input-json "$(envsubst < examples/simple-rnaseq.json)" The above snippet the rnaseq-nf pipeline at this link . The args input field is used to specify the Nextflow command line option -profile that selects the docker profile enabling the use of Docker container. Note pipeline results are stored in the local results directory in the VM running the Nextflow app. To save the result in the DNAnexus project storage, add to the args attribute in the examples/simple-rnaseq.json file, the option --outdir dx://<YOUR PROJECT ID>:/some/output/dir , replacing the placeholder <YOUR PROJECT ID> with the project id that can be found using this oneliner: 1 dx env | grep project | cut -f 2 NOTE: The dx:// pseudo-protocol is used by Nextflow to identify file paths in the DNAnexus storage. Launching nf-core RNAseq pipeline # 1 2 3 4 5 dx run nextflow-app \ --watch \ --delay-workspace-destruction \ --instance-type mem3_ssd3_x12 \ --input-json "$(envsubst < examples/nfcore-rnaseq.json)" The above example launch shows how to run the exection of the nf-core/rnaseq pipeline using the test profile
docs.title: Launch your first pipeline

docs.text: 1 2 3 dx run nextflow-app \ --watch \ --input-json "$(envsubst < examples/hello.json)" The above snippet runs the Nextflow hello pipeline. The Nextflow log file will be uploaded in your DNAnexus project root. You can access with the following command: 1 dx cat nextflow.log
docs.title: Launching classic NF Hello world app

docs.text: 1 2 3 dx run nextflow-app \ --watch \ --input-json "$(envsubst < examples/simple-rnaseq.json)" The above snippet the rnaseq-nf pipeline at this link . The args input field is used to specify the Nextflow command line option -profile that selects the docker profile enabling the use of Docker container. Note pipeline results are stored in the local results directory in the VM running the Nextflow app. To save the result in the DNAnexus project storage, add to the args attribute in the examples/simple-rnaseq.json file, the option --outdir dx://<YOUR PROJECT ID>:/some/output/dir , replacing the placeholder <YOUR PROJECT ID> with the project id that can be found using this oneliner: 1 dx env | grep project | cut -f 2 NOTE: The dx:// pseudo-protocol is used by Nextflow to identify file paths in the DNAnexus storage.
docs.title: Launching simple RNAseq pipeline using container execution

docs.text: 1 2 3 4 5 dx run nextflow-app \ --watch \ --delay-workspace-destruction \ --instance-type mem3_ssd3_x12 \ --input-json "$(envsubst < examples/nfcore-rnaseq.json)" The above example launch shows how to run the exection of the nf-core/rnaseq pipeline using the test profile
docs.title: Launching nf-core RNAseq pipeline
